help.name: mri_normalize
help.description: Normalize the white-matter, optionally based on control points. The input volume is converted into a new volume where white matter image values all range around 110.

optional-flagged.explanation: use n 3d normalization iterations (default=2)
disable 1d normalization
turn non-maximum suppression on (1) or off (0) when using interior of surfaces
interpolate and embed volume to be 256^3
do not conform the volume
perform kinder gentler normalization
use control points file (usually control.dat)
use only control points file
use only control points in label file
use control points in label file
write ctrl point(c) and bias field(b) volumes
use control point with intensity a above target (default=25.0)
use control point with intensity b below target (default=10.0)
use max intensity/mm gradient g (default=1.000)
turn pruning of control points on/off (default=off). pruning useful if white is expanding into gm
Do not use gentle normalization with control points file
optional-flagged.argument: -atlas <path to gca><path to gca transform> <min distance of control points from non-brain>
optional-flagged.explanation: use atlas to exlude control-points from being in non-brain regions
turns off 1d, sets num_3d_iter=1
disable snr normalization
smooth bias field
for debugging
for debugging
load volume and use all points in it that are exactly 110 as control points
load volume and remove all control points that aren't in [min max] in volume
for reading
Output final control points as a volume (only with -aseg)
normalize based on the skelton of the interior of the transformed surface
set random number generator to seed N
print usage

help.example:
mri_normalize SUBJECT/mri/nu.mgz SUBJECT/mri/T1.mgz
Uses the nu volume (nonuniformity corrected volume), and creates the T1 volume, with white matter voxels around 110 image value

mri_normalize -noskull -aseg aseg.mgz -mask brainmask.mgz norm.mgz brain.mgz
Uses the norm volume, and creates the brain volume, making use of the aseg and masking with brainmask
help.references: "Cortical Surface-Based Analysis I: Segmentation and Surface Reconstruction", Dale, A.M., Fischl, B., Sereno, M.I. (1999) NeuroImage 9(2):179-194
